p: Rather than privileging macro over micro, the Global Agenda points to the symbiosis between the two. Local actions can have global impact, the experiences of groups or communities in one part of the world can have resonance elsewhere, and many key issues exceed national borders. One of the impacts of this ‘glocal’ perspective is the deprivileging of previously dominant Western ideas and the indigenization of knowledge and practices. Another is that to be effective social work needs to operate on a glocal basis, taking both local and global circumstances into account and seeking to influence policy in both spheres.
